Still groundbreaking and innovative to this day. Truly goes to show how a masterpiece can stand the test of time, it's not just fun to play it once although that'll be your best playthrough since all the story events haven't been unfolded yet, you can hop back on it anytime you desire and it'll still have the same sense of being unique and fresh. The movement options alone keep the game from going stale, just simply bunny-hopping and gravity gun propelling can get you past an entire chapter in minutes.. if you're reckless enough. There's always the additional achievements and easter eggs on the side which has personally upped my playtime record by 20+ hours. The world is really easy to fall into and get immersed with all the lore and additional functions of the technology within the game. For a 2004 game, it still has me massively impressed not just with what they managed to create with the technology at the time.. but the concepts and ideas that still seem staggering, astounding and modern. For a game priced at 8,19€, I highly recommend it. Overall groundbreaking and essential game. 10/10

Шикарная игра. Отличный сюжет который можно разбирать хоть 5 лет, геймплей, графика и физика поражают даже спустя 17 лет. Внимание к деталям очень хорошее, когда проходишь какое либо место сразу начинаешь думать, что здесь происходило и погружаешься в этот мрачный мир игры. Курто короче.

An actual unbiased review of Half-Life 2:

I first played this game only several months ago and I was initially blown away. The graphics are incredible (given the fact that this game is almost as old as I am), the gameplay and level design is solid, and the environmental and physics sound design is phenomenal. The worldbuilding is masterfully done, painting a bleak picture of a dystopian universe better than any other work of fiction has done.

Level design is excellent, with the game making use of the Source engine to make clever physics-based puzzles involving weights, buoyancy, inertia, and so on. Enemies appear in reasonable quantities, and if you're smart, can be taken out with relative ease by making use of the environment. Though after a while, it does get somewhat predictable if enemies ALWAYS spawn right next to a convenient explosive barrel. What's even in those barrels, anyway? Straight gunpowder? Ammunition? Who knows... Anyway, for it's few flaws, I find HL2's levels to always be unique and fresh.

For 2004, the graphics are drop-dead gorgeous. As someone who's used to dated graphics or at least turning them to ultra-low to just barely squeeze past 50 fps, the game runs exceptionally well on any less-than-slightly-modern rig. Even integrated graphics can run the game on max or nearly-maxed settings. Fire effects, dynamic lighting, particles, water effects, reflections, shadows, diffraction, etc. are all really visually great. I see people complaining that HL2 has crap graphics, but what they fail to take into account is that the Source engine walked so that everything else to come could run. To my knowledge, Source is the first engine to combine (mostly) realistic physics with several shaders, high-res textures, and complex scenes. Even my #1 favorite game, Titanfall 2, uses the Source engine, and it is visually stunning, even in 2022. If Gaben had not blessed us with Half-Life 2, the gaming world would have been a lot less interesting and moddable.

Now, the biggest complaint I have with HL2 (and its two sequels) as opposed to HL1 is its atrocious weapon sandbox. I don't mean that the weapons don't do their jobs, as I find them to be very well balanced and each has its specific role, but they just feel... underpowered in every sense. Almost every weapon is woefully inaccurate, with nearly none of your shots landing beyond 20 meters, the worst offender being the SMG with a very wide cone of fire and no first shot accuracy bonus. Burst control is practically useless with any weapon, so combat feels less tactical and more about trading bullets until either you or your enemy's health drops to zero. Boss enemies are a different story, however, with the rocket launcher being great for taking out striders and close-quarters engagements with those big antlion beasts (can't remember their names) being great times to use weapons other than the Combine rifle and crossbow. The greatest factor in the wimpy feeling of the weapons is definitely their sub-par sound design and uninspired animations. The pistol, for example, makes a sound similar to a edited one of a car quickly going over a speedbump, and the reload animation is merely holding it slightly to the right, pointing it slightly up, barely visibly swapping mags, and tapping the mag well. The SMG's firing animation is just a 2-frame cycle of the gun being forward, then backward, then forward again. Very bland and uninteresting.

Another serious issue I have with this game is the terrible lack of replay value. The cinematic moments where you get to observe the world and get a look into this bleak universe work well, such as witnessing metrocops raiding appartment complexes because of a miscount, watching as rebels and vortigaunts work in the background to fit your car or watercraft with a neat gun, and so on work very well, as they don't do much to bring the story to a grinding halt, but instead give you a short breather. These are fine, but the bad aspect comes when you get locked in a room and are forced to listen to five minutes of dialog. During your first playthrough, this was fine, as it was fresh and you got to play around with the little gizmos scattered around, like a tiny teleporter that you could put a potted cactus in, turn on, and watch as it is instantaneously repositioned to the other end.  The second and following playthroughs, however, lose this novelty instantly. As you already know the characters, hearing banal talk about insufferable "domesticated" headcrabs and "highly interesting" scientific research with resonance cascade events no longer brings anything meaningful. It's like watching a murder mystery movie over again; you already know what's going to happen, and nothing you do will change it. Half the time I'm just fighting the intense urge to rocket-jump onto an unreachable shelf or just end it all with a grenade.

BEWARE OF SPOILERS BEYOND THIS POINT

The story is the main selling point of Half-Life 2, and Half-Life in general. You play as Gordon Freeman, the mute man in the orange hazard suit. Following the catastrophic Black Mesa incident (as seen in HL1), the Freeman accepts a nebulous contractual agreement presented to him by the mysterious "G-Man", an otherworldly being taking the form of an uncanny businessman. Waking up an indeterminate amount of time later, Gordon Freeman finds that the world has been overrun by an interdimensional alien civilization, known simply as "The Combine". The remnants of humanity left over following the Seven Hour War inhabit old Eastern European cities, now repurposed by the Combine as a headquarters for their operations on Earth. It is up to The Freeman to act as the savior of the human race to strike back against the invaders and liberate Earth from their grasp. You will have to fight through humans who have forsaken their brothers and sisters in order to live more comfortable lives by becoming Civil Protection Units or Combine Soldiers, alien life from the borderworld Xen, zombies, and other alien creatures enslaved by the Combine. 

Personally, I was immediately hooked when playing through the HL games. The intrigue, the mystery, the deceit, the horror, the dismal fate faced by the human race kept me really invested in seeing where things would go. Having a silent protagonist in the form of Gordon Freeman, although probably just a technical limitation in HL1, really doesn't detract from his character, if anything making him a fascinating specimen of storytelling. Freeman takes the trope of putting YOU in the hero's shoes a step further than what Halo CE and 2 did with just having a blank personality; with Gordon, one can never know his true intentions, personality, or anything of the sort. He's just the right man at the wrong place. Is he traumatized to the point of becoming a mute? Is he a deranged psychopath? Is he even human? Is he... real? Or is he, in his mere existence, breaking the fourth wall in that he is directly controlled by the person playing the game? For a franchise that's been around for longer than many people who have played it, the community is still at a loss for who G-man is, what the Nihilanth's people are/were, what other races were enslaved by the combine, why Gordon was selected as the savior of humanity, or if Gordon even wears a helmet in the first place!

In conclusion, if you are wondering if you should buy and play Half-Life 2, the the answer is most certainly a yes. However, I don't recommend this game *as much* as I recommend HL1. I have nearly 9 times as many hours in the original as I do this one. Just consider that this will be a one-time experience, unless you use mods. I've heard MMod is great, and you can get several fan games from ModDB.
